What is the size of the largest $A\subseteq \{1,\ldots,N\}$ such that, for all $\emptyset\neq S\subseteq A$, $\sum_{n\in S}n$ is not a square?



Erd\H{o}s observed that $\lvert A\rvert \gg N^{1/3}$ is possible, taking the first $\approx N^{1/3}$ multiples of some prime $p\approx N^{2/3}$.

Essentially solved by Nguyen and Vu \cite{NgVu10}, who proved that $\lvert A\rvert\ll N^{1/3}(\log N)^{O(1)}$.

See also [438].

This question was {IMAGE=587Picture,asked by Erd\H{o}s to a young Terence Tao in 1985}. We thank Tao for sharing this memory and a {IMAGE=587Letter,letter of Erd\H{o}s describing the problem}.




References


[NgVu10] Nguyen, Hoi H. and Vu, Van H., Squares in sumsets. An irregular mind (2010), 491-524.
